| **Abstract**                  | Our main question for this project is to see the ***role that mental disorders play in our world***. We can get a better understanding of how mental health plays into people's lives since it recently became acknowledged as a serious problem. To address this concern, we will observe the rates of mental disorders per country/region and compare it with the *types of government* and *unemployment rates*. | **1.0 Introduction**          | In this project, our group will be focusing on the prevalence of mental health disorders in different countries. The exact mental health disorders we're interested in analyzing include schizophrenia, anxiety, bipolar disorder, eating disorder, drug use disorder, depressive disorder, and alcohol use disorder. We hope that in doing this research, clear insight is provided regarding steps that countries with poor mental health could take which would improve the quality of life and ultimately reduce mental health disorders for the global community.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
+-------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **2.0 Design Situation**      | **Project framing:** The topic of concern we are focusing on is mental health disorders around the world. More specifically, we want to investigate if mental health disorders are related to government type and unemployment. For example, we want to see the prevalence of mental health disorders on a global scale and dig into whether governments are exacerbating those issues in terms of social resources for the people in that nation. Key elements include population health, global trends, and social structure in relation to the percentage of mental illnesses. **Human values:** The human values connected to our topic of concern are power and awareness. The values originate from compassion as our project aims to find different correlations to improve global mental health disorders. We also based our definition of power from Data Feminism into our human value. Power is an important value because having the power to be influential can help spread awareness. We are also making sure that we spread awareness of factors that affect mental health issues and well-being: environmental factors, social and economic circumstances, and individual attributes and behaviors. **Stakeholders** The *direct stakeholders* are government officials, physicians (i.e. psychiatrists and psychologists) and organizations (i.e. World Health Organization). As direct stakeholders, they have the power to influence and implement change to provide mental health resources for the people. Physicians are able to have a better understanding of how they can be the source of assistance for their patients. Organizations can use this data to provide assistance to government officials. *Indirect stakeholders* are citizens because they may not know that this data is being collected and used to analyze different mental health issues globally. **Harms and benefits:** The potential *benefits* are mental health issues are improved for the indirect stakeholders and the government can have an idea of ways that they can implement change to improve the well-being of their citizens. The potential harm is that there is a wide difference between cultures so some implementations may not work for different cultures. While we can avoid the potential harm, we might not be able to avoid the *unanticipated consequences*. If the government has implemented some type of change, the people could react negatively which could cause an increase in mental health issues |
+-------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **3.0 Research questions**    | **1: Which continent/region has the most mental health problems by the most recent date?** *We will answer this by grouping each of the regions together. We will then filter out the most recent date. Afterwards, we will take the average of all of the mental health issues and pull the Region that has the highest percentage.* **2: What is the most prevalent mental health problem currently?** *We would take the average of each mental health column. Whichever has the highest average is the most common mental health issue that can be seen all around the world* **3: Which country has the lowest percentage of mental health issues currently?** *We will do the same thing as the first question, but instead of finding the largest percentage, we would find the smallest.* **4: What is the most prevalent mental health problem in the first recorded time?** *We would approach this question by doing the same thing as question two but instead of max, do min. Having these two values will act as a good indicator as to how metal health issues have changed and evolved over time.* **5: What type of government produces the lowest prevalence of mental illnesses?** *We will approach this question by grouping the Regimes and take the average of each mental illness in each regime. We will then filter out the lowest average and pull the regime that reflects that value.***6: How does unemployment rates correlate to mental health issues?** *We approached this question by takin the average of all the mental health issues. Then, we merged that dataset with the unemployment dataset. After that, we took the highest unemploymen rate, lowest unemployment rate, lowest mental helath rate and the highest mental health rate to see if we can find a clear correlation between those numbers.*                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
+-------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **4.0 The Dataset**           | Data Provenance: The dataset that we chose to focus on is called "prevalence-by-mental-and-subset-use-disorder." We found this dataset from Our World in Data which is an organization sponsored by the University of Oxford. In this dataset country populations and their percentage of different mental health issues are represented. It contains records from every country, at least those formally recognized by the site, and some are combined into areas such as the "Middle east and North Africa''. Each group has data from each year between **1990 to 2019** on the percentage of multiple mental illnesses; more specifically, schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, eating disorders, drug use, depression, and alcohol use. It contains ***8221 records, has a range of 40 years for each country, and has 10 columns that represent different mental health issues that we will be focusing on.*** We obtained the data from Our World in Data site which provides *accessible data* to the general public without requirements on inclusion in government or certain research institutions. This dataset combines data collected by the Global Health Data Exchange, which is owned by the University of Washington. Much of the data in the Global Health Data Exchange is received from studies done by the IPUMS, ICPSR, and the World Bank, credible organizations where data is collected in order to create a global understanding for institutional change. It is held secure and cannot be modified and re-entered into the databases. ***The data we are using comes from a string of credible and trustworthy sources of NGO's and research universities where data collection is not for monetary goals***, however one limitation in the provenance is that we cannot see the specific collection process and cannot ensure it was accurately or ethically produced, beyond the credibility of the organizations. Our second dataset to supplement our analysis is Autocracies of the World Dataset. from the Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies within Stanford University which creates a measure of credibility. It classifies the regime types of governments from 1950-2012 into democracy, multiparty, single party, military, and monarchy. The dataset includes rows for every year for countries with populations of 500,000 or greater and has 8,629 observations. Along with the regime classification column, it includes many columns on country classifications like continent, code, regime change, and leadership. Lastly, we used a third dataset which contains data regarding unemployment rate around the world. This dataset has variables which describe the Entity, Code, Year, and Unemployment, which was calculated by using the total percent of labor force and modeling the international labor organization estimate.

| **5.0 Expected Implications** | Some expected implications that could take place from this research are that policy makers of each country might take more steps to implement policies that would better the well-being of their people. Different people from all over the world might look at the information that we gathered and choose to take steps to try and better their mental health by comparing their well-being to the people in their country. Technologists might also choose to conduct more research to look into what might be causing the mental health issues in each region.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     |
+-------------------------------+----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| **6.0 Limitations**           | Some limitations that we feel are important to mention include that there are some countries that do not take mental health very seriously. The implications of this could mean that there is little to no research in that country to track the mental health issues of their people which would affect the data for that country. Accordingly, in some countries, it is not normal to talk about mental health issues, so, even if there was research conducted, it could be skewed because of response bias. Correspondingly, in this dataset, we do not have the information to know what exactly is the root cause of those mental health issues. We do not know if it has something to do with the government, the country's GDP, or the poverty rate. Overall, we simply do not have that information. Finally, the government dataset only goes to the year 2012 and there are some regions that do not have a listed regime type, so all the other datasets needed to be altered accordingly.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |

# Summary Information:
```{r, include = T, echo = FALSE, warning = FALSE}
library(dplyr)
library(reshape2)
source("../source/aggregate_file.R")
```
Searching for the differing prevalence of mental health, we have found an interesting understanding of its layout in the world. The most prevalent mental health problem at this time among all the countries is `r most_prevelant_problem` and so we have identified this as the most widespread issue that needs to be addressed globally. This is a consistent problem, as the most prevalent mental health problem in the first recorded year was also `r most_prevelant_problem_early`. The country with the most mental health problems by the most recent date, which can be understood as the place where mental health has to be most prioritized is `r highest_region` with an average rate `highest_amount`. Lessons can be extrapolated from the country with the lowest prevalence of mental illnesses, `r lowest_region`, on how governments can minimize mental illnesses to better serve their citizens. The type of government that produces the lowest prevalence of mental illnesses is `r lowest_prevalence`, however its important to recognize that this may be skewed because authoritative countries may have under reported values, or there may be going on that we cannot see in the collection process, and this limitation applies to the lowest country. We don't quite see a correlation between mental illness rates and the unemployment-rate as many countries have higher or lower unemployment rates unrelated to a pattern.

# Charts

## Chart 1

```{r, source, include = T, echo = FALSE, warning = FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
source("../source/Chart_1_Athena.R")
```

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(plotly)
plot(schiz_unemp)
```

This is a scatterplot that shows the unemployment rates and Schizophrenia rates of all the countries in 2019. The purpose of this scatter plot is to show the correlation between the rate of Schizophrenia and the unemployment rate. From this chart, we do not see a clear correlation. That means there is no association between Schizophrenia and unemployment rate. 

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(ggplot2)
plot(alc_unemp)
```

This is a scatter plot that shows the unemployment rate and the rate of alcohol use disorders. The purpose is to show if there is a correlation between these two variables. From the chart, we can deduce that there is a slight correlation. As the rate of unemployment increases, the rate of alcohol use disorder increases. 

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(ggplot2)
plot(depressive_unemp)
```

This is the scatter plot that shows depressive disorders rates and unemployment rate. The purpose of this is to show if there is a correlation between unemployment rate and depressive disorder rates. From this chart, we deduce that there is no correlation because it is close to being a straight line. 

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(ggplot2)
plot(drug_use_unemp)
```

This scatter plot shows the correlation between unemployment rate and drug use disorder rates. Each point shows a country. From this chart, we can see that there is no correlation.

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(ggplot2)
plot(bipolar_dis_unemp)
```

This is a scatter plot to show if there is a correlation between two points. We do not see a correlation between the unemployment rate and the bipolar disorders rates. 

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(ggplot2)
plot(anxiety_unemp)
```

This scatter plot shows points of each country of the anxiety disorder rates and unemployment rates. From this chart, we can deduce that there is no clear correlation. 

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(ggplot2)
plot(eating_disorder_unemp)
```

This scatter plot shows the points of each country of the eating disorder rates and the unemployment rate. It slightly creates a straight line, which means that there is no correlation.

This chart shows the prevalence of mental illnesses around the world. The more red the location, the more prevalent mental illnesses are. The data represented through this map is the mean of all mental illnesses that we investigated; schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, etc (can you please list them all). This resulted in one average mental illness rate per entity.  This is how we chose to represent the significance of mental health around the world. Governments of the locations with the more prevalent ratings of mental illnesses should step up and implement actionable items to improve the mental health of their citizens

## Chart 3

```{r, include=F}
library(ggplot2)
setwd("../source")
source("chart_3.R")
```

```{r, include=T, echo=F}
library(ggplot2)
plot(chart_3)
```
This chart shows the relationship between the government type of a country and the prevalence of mental disorders. The bars are made of stacks of each different illness prevalence bar for each regime type which creates a bar chart where we can compare the average mental illness prevalences. Democracies seem to have the highest average disorder rates, which could be emblematic of having to engage with government and the frustration around that, but it could also be that mental disorder rates are more freely recorded in democracies. Depressive and anxiety disorders are the most prevalent across the board that slightly vary. The most clear differences are that alcohol use disorders are much less prevalent in monarchies and depressive drug use disorders are higher in democracies.
